answer: Programming is the process of creating instructions for computers to execute tasks using programming languages.
An algorithm is a step-by-step procedure or set of rules designed to solve a specific problem or perform a computation.
A variable is a named storage location in memory that holds a value which can change during program execution.
A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task and can accept inputs and return outputs.
A loop is a programming construct that repeats a block of code multiple times until a specified condition is met.
A conditional statement is a programming construct that executes different code blocks based on whether a condition is true or false.
Debugging is the process of identifying, analyzing, and removing errors or bugs from computer programs.
A compiler is a program that translates source code written in a high-level programming language into machine code or executable form.
An interpreter is a program that directly executes code line by line without requiring prior compilation into machine code.
Syntax refers to the set of rules that define the structure and valid combinations of symbols in a programming language.
Java is a high-level, object-oriented programming language designed to be platform-independent and used to build various types of applications.
JVM (Java Virtual Machine) is an abstract computing machine that enables computers to run Java programs by converting bytecode into machine-specific code.
JDK (Java Development Kit) is a software development environment that includes tools for developing, debugging, and running Java applications.
JRE (Java Runtime Environment) provides the libraries and JVM needed to run Java applications but does not include development tools.

Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) in Java is a programming paradigm based on objects that contain data and methods, emphasizing concepts like encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism, and abstraction.
A class is a blueprint or template for creating objects that defines attributes (data) and methods (behavior) that the objects will have.
An object is an instance of a class that contains actual values for the attributes and can perform actions defined by the class methods.
Inheritance is an OOP concept where a class (child/subclass) derives properties and methods from another class (parent/superclass), promoting code reusability.
Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common parent class and enables methods to perform different tasks based on the object calling them.
Encapsulation is the bundling of data and methods within a class while restricting direct access to some components using access modifiers like private, public, and protected.
Abstraction is the concept of hiding complex implementation details and showing only essential features of an object, achieved through abstract classes and interfaces.
An interface is a contract in Java that defines a set of abstract methods that implementing classes must provide, supporting multiple inheritance and abstraction.
Exception handling is a mechanism to handle runtime errors gracefully using try, catch, finally, throw, and throws keywords to maintain normal program flow.
Multithreading is the concurrent execution of multiple threads within a single process, allowing efficient utilization of CPU resources and improved performance.
A constructor is a special method in a class that is automatically called when an object is created, used to initialize the object's attributes.
Spring Boot is an extension of the Spring Framework that simplifies building production-ready Java applications with minimal configuration and embedded servers.
Spring Framework is a comprehensive Java framework that provides infrastructure support for developing enterprise applications with features like dependency injection and aspect-oriented programming.
Dependency Injection is a design pattern where objects receive their dependencies from external sources rather than creating them, promoting loose coupling and testability.
IoC (Inversion of Control) is a principle where the control of object creation and lifecycle is transferred from the application code to a framework or container.
REST API in Spring Boot is a web service that follows REST architectural principles, allowing communication between client and server using HTTP methods.
An annotation is a form of metadata that provides information about the program but is not part of the program itself, used extensively in Java frameworks like Spring.
A data structure is a specialized format for organizing, storing, and managing data efficiently to enable effective access and modification.
An array is a collection of elements of the same data type stored in contiguous memory locations, accessed using an index.
A linked list is a linear data structure where elements (nodes) are connected using pointers, with each node containing data and a reference to the next node.
A stack is a linear data structure that follows the Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle, where elements are added and removed from the same end called the top.
A queue is a linear data structure that follows the First-In-First-Out (FIFO) principle, where elements are added at the rear and removed from the front.
A tree is a hierarchical data structure consisting of nodes connected by edges, with a root node at the top and child nodes branching below.
A binary tree is a tree data structure where each node has at most two children, referred to as the left child and right child.
A graph is a non-linear data structure consisting of vertices (nodes) connected by edges, used to represent relationships between objects.
Hashing is a technique that maps data of arbitrary size to fixed-size values using a hash function, enabling fast data retrieval and storage.
Time complexity is a measure of the amount of time an algorithm takes to complete as a function of the input size, typically expressed using Big O notation.
Space complexity is a measure of the amount of memory an algorithm uses as a function of the input size, including both auxiliary space and input space.
Big O notation is a mathematical notation used to describe the upper bound of an algorithm's time or space complexity in terms of input size.
Recursion is a programming technique where a function calls itself to solve a problem by breaking it down into smaller subproblems of the same type.
Sorting is the process of arranging elements in a specific order (ascending or descending) using algorithms like bubble sort, merge sort, and quick sort.
Searching is the process of finding a specific element in a data structure using algorithms like linear search and binary search.
DBMS (Database Management System) is software that enables users to create, manage, and manipulate databases efficiently while ensuring data security and integrity.
A database is an organized collection of structured data stored electronically, designed for efficient storage, retrieval, and management.
RDBMS (Relational Database Management System) is a type of DBMS that stores data in tables with rows and columns, using SQL for data manipulation.
A table is a collection of related data organized in rows and columns within a database, where each row represents a record and each column represents an attribute.
A primary key is a unique identifier for each record in a database table that ensures no duplicate or null values exist for that column.
A foreign key is a column or set of columns in one table that references the primary key of another table, establishing a relationship between the two tables.
Normalization is the process of organizing database tables to reduce redundancy and dependency by dividing large tables into smaller, related tables.
A transaction is a sequence of database operations that are executed as a single unit of work, ensuring data consistency and integrity.
ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) are a set of principles that guarantee reliable processing of database transactions.
Indexing is a database optimization technique that creates a data structure to improve the speed of data retrieval operations on a table.
A join is a SQL operation that combines rows from two or more tables based on a related column, enabling retrieval of data from multiple tables.
A view is a virtual table in a database that is based on the result of a SQL query, providing a way to simplify complex queries and enhance security.
SQL (Structured Query Language) is a standardized programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases through queries and commands.
A query is a request for data or information from a database, typically written in SQL to retrieve, insert, update, or delete data.
SELECT statement is a SQL command used to retrieve data from one or more tables in a database, specifying which columns and rows to return.
WHERE clause is a SQL component used to filter records based on specified conditions, returning only rows that meet the criteria.
GROUP BY is a SQL clause that groups rows with the same values in specified columns, often used with aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM, and AVG.
HAVING clause is a SQL component used to filter grouped records based on aggregate function results, similar to WHERE but applied after grouping.
ORDER BY is a SQL clause used to sort the result set in ascending or descending order based on one or more columns.
A subquery is a query nested inside another SQL query, used to provide data to the outer query and enable complex data retrieval operations.
DDL (Data Definition Language) is a subset of SQL used to define and modify database structures, including CREATE, ALTER, DROP, and TRUNCATE commands.
DML (Data Manipulation Language) is a subset of SQL used to manipulate data within tables, including SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE commands.
DCL (Data Control Language) is a subset of SQL used to control access to data in the database, including GRANT and REVOKE commands.
TCL (Transaction Control Language) is a subset of SQL used to manage transactions in the database, including COMMIT, ROLLBACK, and SAVEPOINT commands.
MongoDB is a popular NoSQL database that stores data in flexible, JSON-like documents, providing high performance, scalability, and flexibility.
NoSQL is a type of database that provides a mechanism for storage and retrieval of data modeled in ways other than tabular relations, designed for distributed data stores.
A document in MongoDB is a record stored in BSON format (similar to JSON) that contains field-value pairs, serving as the basic unit of data.
A collection in MongoDB is a group of documents, similar to a table in relational databases, but without a fixed schema.
BSON (Binary JSON) is a binary-encoded serialization format used by MongoDB to store documents and make remote procedure calls, extending JSON with additional data types.
A schema-less database is a database that does not require a predefined structure for data, allowing documents in the same collection to have different fields.
Replication in MongoDB is the process of synchronizing data across multiple servers to ensure data availability, redundancy, and fault tolerance.
Sharding is a method of distributing data across multiple machines in MongoDB, enabling horizontal scaling by partitioning large datasets.
An API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate and interact with each other.
REST API (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for designing networked applications using HTTP requests to access and manipulate data.
RESTful web services are web services that follow REST architectural principles, using standard HTTP methods and stateless communication between client and server.
HTTP methods are standard operations used in REST APIs including GET (retrieve data), POST (create data), PUT (update data), and DELETE (remove data).
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a lightweight data-interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write and easy for machines to parse and generate.
XML (Extensible Markup Language) is a markup language that defines rules for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.
An API endpoint is a specific URL where an API can access the resources it needs, serving as a communication point between the client and server.
SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) is a protocol for exchanging structured information in web services using XML-based messaging.
HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is an application-layer protocol used for transmitting hypermedia documents and enabling communication between web browsers and servers.
HTTPS (HTTP Secure) is an extension of HTTP that uses encryption (SSL/TLS) to secure communication between client and server, protecting data from eavesdropping.
An HTTP request is a message sent by a client to a server to request access to a resource, containing method, headers, and optionally a body.
An HTTP response is a message sent by a server back to the client in response to an HTTP request, containing status code, headers, and optionally a body.
A status code is a three-digit number returned by a server in an HTTP response indicating the result of the request, such as 200 (OK), 404 (Not Found), or 500 (Server Error).
A cookie is a small piece of data stored on the user's browser by a website, used to remember information about the user such as login status or preferences.
A session is a temporary interaction between a user and a web application, maintained on the server side to store user-specific data across multiple requests.
HTTP headers are key-value pairs sent in HTTP requests and responses that provide additional information about the request or response, such as content type or authentication.
GET method is an HTTP request method used to retrieve data from a server without modifying it, with parameters typically sent in the URL.
POST method is an HTTP request method used to send data to a server to create or update a resource, with data sent in the request body.
C is a general-purpose, procedural programming language developed in 1972, known for its efficiency and close-to-hardware capabilities, widely used in system programming.
A pointer is a variable in C that stores the memory address of another variable, enabling direct memory manipulation and efficient data structure implementations.
Memory allocation is the process of assigning memory space to variables during program execution, either statically at compile time or dynamically at runtime using functions like malloc.
A structure in C is a user-defined data type that groups variables of different data types under a single name, enabling organized data representation.
An array in C is a collection of elements of the same data type stored in contiguous memory locations, accessed using an index starting from 0.
A function in C is a block of reusable code that performs a specific task, can accept parameters, and may return a value to the caller.
A preprocessor directive is a command in C that begins with # and is processed before compilation, used for file inclusion, macro definition, and conditional compilation.
A header file is a file in C with .h extension that contains function declarations, macro definitions, and data types, included in programs using the #include directive.
C++ is a general-purpose, object-oriented programming language that extends C with features like classes, inheritance, polymorphism, and templates.
OOP in C++ is a programming paradigm based on objects and classes, implementing concepts like encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism, and abstraction.
A class in C++ is a user-defined data type that serves as a blueprint for creating objects, encapsulating data members and member functions.
A constructor in C++ is a special member function with the same name as the class that is automatically called when an object is created to initialize its data members.
A destructor in C++ is a special member function with the same name as the class preceded by a tilde (~) that is automatically called when an object is destroyed to release resources.
Operator overloading in C++ is a feature that allows operators to be redefined and used with user-defined data types, providing custom behavior for standard operators.
STL (Standard Template Library) is a powerful library in C++ that provides common data structures and algorithms through templates, including containers, iterators, and algorithms.
A virtual function in C++ is a member function declared with the virtual keyword that can be overridden in derived classes, enabling runtime polymorphism.
A friend function in C++ is a function that is not a member of a class but has access to its private and protected members, declared using the friend keyword.
A computer network is a collection of interconnected devices that can communicate and share resources with each other through wired or wireless connections.
The Internet is a global network of interconnected computer networks that use standard protocols to connect billions of devices worldwide, enabling information exchange.
An IP address (Internet Protocol address) is a unique numerical identifier assigned to each device on a network, used for routing data packets to their destination.
A MAC address (Media Access Control address) is a unique hardware identifier assigned to network interface cards by manufacturers, used for communication within a local network.
DNS (Domain Name System) is a hierarchical naming system that translates human-readable domain names (like google.com) into IP addresses that computers use to identify each other.
The OSI model (Open Systems Interconnection) is a conceptual framework with seven layers that standardizes network communication functions, from physical transmission to application-level processes.
The TCP/IP model is a four-layer networking framework that describes how data should be packetized, addressed, transmitted, routed, and received on the Internet.
A router is a networking device that forwards data packets between computer networks, directing traffic based on IP addresses to ensure data reaches its destination.
A switch is a networking device that connects devices within a local network and uses MAC addresses to forward data only to the intended recipient device.
A protocol is a set of rules and standards that define how data is transmitted and received over a network, ensuring devices can communicate effectively.
Bandwidth is the maximum rate at which data can be transferred over a network connection in a given time period, typically measured in bits per second (bps).
Latency is the time delay between sending a data packet and receiving it at its destination, typically measured in milliseconds, affecting network responsiveness.
LAN (Local Area Network) covers a small geographic area, WAN (Wide Area Network) spans large distances, and MAN (Metropolitan Area Network) covers a city-sized area.
A subnet is a logical subdivision of an IP network that divides a larger network into smaller, manageable segments for improved performance and security.
A firewall is a security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules, protecting networks from unauthorized access.
An operating system is system software that manages computer hardware and software resources and provides common services for application programs.
A process is an instance of a program in execution, containing program code, current activity, and allocated system resources like memory and CPU time.
A thread is the smallest unit of execution within a process, allowing multiple operations to run concurrently while sharing the same memory space.
Multitasking is the ability of an operating system to execute multiple tasks or processes concurrently by rapidly switching between them, giving the illusion of simultaneous execution.
Virtual memory is a memory management technique that uses hard disk space as an extension of RAM, allowing systems to run larger programs than physical memory would permit.
Paging is a memory management scheme that divides memory into fixed-size blocks called pages, allowing non-contiguous memory allocation and efficient memory usage.
Segmentation is a memory management technique that divides memory into variable-sized segments based on logical divisions of a program, such as code, data, and stack.
Deadlock is a situation in operating systems where two or more processes are unable to proceed because each is waiting for resources held by the other.
Scheduling is the process by which an operating system determines which process or thread should use the CPU at any given time, using algorithms to optimize performance.
The kernel is the core component of an operating system that manages system resources, provides hardware abstraction, and facilitates communication between hardware and software.
A system call is a programmatic interface through which a program requests services from the operating system kernel, such as file operations or process management.
A file system is a method and data structure that an operating system uses to organize, store, retrieve, and manage files on storage devices.
A semaphore is a synchronization primitive used in operating systems to control access to shared resources and coordinate processes, preventing race conditions.
Mutual exclusion is a concurrency control principle that ensures only one process can access a critical section or shared resource at a time, preventing conflicts.
